Award.AwardTitle: Integrated analysis of pollen recognition and double fertilization mechanisms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fertilization and seed production in flowering plants relies on the delivery of two sperm to female gametes by a pollen tube. The success of the long and rapid journey of the pollen tube relies on constant signaling between the pollen tube cell and the cells of the pistil. Pollen tubes must find specific cellular targets, they must burst when they arrive at the target, and their sperm must fuse with female gametes. These events are all essential for seed production, which is central to agricultural production and food security. Our goal is to understand the molecules that mediate exchanges between pollen and pistil. Cellular interactions between pollen and pistil are mediated by extracellular signaling exchanges occurring in a complex environment where multiple pollen tubes are competing for a limited number of ovules. Ovules are the structures where female gametes develop and that mature into seeds (e.g. rice grains and corn kernels) only after successful fertilization by a pollen tube. The United States will be better able to contribute to scientific progress when our scientists represent the full diversity of our nation. This project will provide cutting edge training in biological imaging, genetics and genomics for early-stage students from groups that have not traditionally been represented in US science. These students will join a team of graduate students and a post-doctoral researcher who will also receive training through this project.

This project will use unique molecular tools to define: 1) Pollen components of the signaling system that results in cessation of tube growth and sperm release in the ovule, 2) Novel components of the mechanisms required for gamete fusion, and 3) How gamete fusion triggers a mechanism that prevents multiple pollen tubes from entering a single ovule.This project will take an integrated approach to the study of fertilization in flowering plants. The molecules that must be displayed by the pollen tube for recognition by the female will be discovered. The project will also define novel components of the gamete fusion mechanism and test hypotheses aimed at understanding how gamete fusion blocks attraction of subsequent pollen tubes. The project takes advantage of unique expertise in imaging, genetics, and genomics to understand how pollen-pistil interactions are integrated to maximize seed production. Defining the molecular exchanges between pollen and pistil that maximize reproductive success will transform our ability to generate new crop varieties with resilient pollination systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most of the crops that are critical for our diet and that of livestock require fertilization for their production. These include grains of rice and wheat, kernels of corn, and fruits like tomato and apple. All of these critical agriculture products require a pollen cell to elongate a projection that can burrow its way through floral tissue to deliver sperm to female gametes for fertilization. This microscopic process happens quickly (less than a day for the crops mentioned above) and requires a series of perfectly orchestrated interactions between the pollen tube, the sperm, and several different floral cell types. The goal of our work is to understand how this system is coordinated by the molecules (usually proteins) that are essential for this process.

 

This project allowed us to explain in molecular terms how sperm cells fuse their plasma membrane with that of the egg and central cell. These twin cellular fusion events are at the heart of fertilization and are required for all of the crops mentioned above. In collaboration with a group of structural biology experts, we found that the sperm-expressed protein HAP2 has the same three-dimensional shape as proteins that allow viruses to enter host cells. We showed that HAP2 initiates fertilization in flowering plants by inserting into the plasma membrane of the female gametes. We also identified the part of the HAP2 protein that inserts into the female gamete membrane. These results, and the finding that HAP2 is at the core of the fertilization mechanism in a wide array of organisms, have very interesting implications for the evolution of reproduction. The results suggest that the mechanism that complex organisms use to reproduce may have been borrowed from viruses. Importantly, a molecular understanding of gamete fusion will facilitate efforts to control reproduction of harmful organisms like the parasite that causes malaria and enable reproduction of helpful organisms like crop plants.

This project also allowed us to gain unprecedented information about the genes that the pollen tube expresses as it grows through floral tissue. We developed a technique that allowed us to distinguish pollen gene activity from floral gene activity, which allowed us to determine exactly how these cells and tissues respond to each other as they interact. We found that the pollen tube expresses many small proteins that are likely to be involved in signaling to itself and to female cells to ensure fertility. We also carefully defined the nature of the cellular interactions between the pollen tube and cells within the flower that are required for release of the sperm cells - an essential step for fertilization. 

This project enabled three graduate students to work toward their PhD degree. Two of the students supported by this project have successfully defended their thesis and are pursuing postdoctoral research with the goal of obtaining a career as research scientists. The third student is in the final stages of the PhD and also plans a career in research. This project allowed us to form a partnership with Tougaloo College that allowed three different students to participate in this research project for either one or two summers.
